lens_1.label: lens_1

parameters.text: We know our overage opportunity size, but how are our opportunities distributed around the world? Looks like they're concentrated in a few key countries....

Calculating the standard deviation in your data can be valuable for a number of contexts, whether it's looking at deal size, case age, rep performance or global revenue.

You can even chart +/-3 standard deviations around the mean to see if any values really stand out!
Want to know how varied the values are in your dataset? Dynamically calculate & chart the standard deviation. Time for SAQL!

The standard deviation tells you, on average, how far away each value in your dataset is from the mean of your dataset. 

Large standard deviations mean that you have a lot of values that are far away from the average, while small standard deviations mean your data is more clustered around the average.

In this example, we see an average deal size of ~$28M, but the standard deviation is ~$38M, meaning our deal sizes are incredibly varied. When we chart 1 standard deviation above the mean and one below, Canada, USA and Japan are quickly identified as outliers.

f = foreach f generate avg('Amount') as 'Amount','Billing_Country' as 'Billing_Country', 
avg(avg('Amount')) over([..] partition by 'all') as 'average',
avg(avg('Amount')) over([..] partition by 'all') + max(max('stddev')) over([..] partition by 'all') as '+1STDDEV',
avg(avg('Amount')) over([..] partition by 'all') - max(max('stddev')) over([..] partition by 'all') as '-1STDDEV';

The stddevp SAQL function makes it easy to calculate standard deviation in the query. 

In the SAQL Query section below, we first calculate the total opportunity amount for each country, then use stddevp to calculate the standard deviation.

We then chart +/- 1 standard deviation around the mean. This quickly shows us that our standard deviation is so large that 1 std dev below the mean is negative!

r = group q by 'Billing_Country';
r = foreach r generate sum('Amount') as 'Amount',first('Billing_Country') as 'Billing_Country';
Standard Deviation! Here's where we calculate it with the stddevp function.

r = group r by all;
r = foreach r generate stddevp('Amount') as 'stddevp_Amount',first('Billing_Country') as 'Billing_Country';
We get a little fancy here, bringing the q and r streams together:total opportunity amount by country and the standard deviation.
Calculate the sum of opportunity amount for each billing country.
Here, we calculate the average opportunity amount, chart +/- 1 standard deviation around the average, and assign the labels
